Award.AwardTitle: Mechanical Behavior of Polymer-Fullerene Blends for Photovoltaic Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding to study relationships between the mechanical behavior and optoelectronic performance of polymer-fullerene blend films for photovoltaic device applications, i.e. solar cells. The principle investigators will consider how morphological features of the blend film affect both the mechanical and electrical properties of the active layers, and how these properties are coupled and modified through material selection and processing conditions. A focus will be on characterizing the mechanical properties and the physical mechanisms of performance variation in devices for different deformation modes. To analyze this system, a combination of experimental and computational investigations will be conducted. The experimental research will combine thin-film mechanics and optoelectronic device measurements along with detailed morphological characterization. A micromechanical model will be developed based on a multi-phase model consisting of pure polymer and fullerene phases, and a miscible phase. A non-linear finite element method will then be applied to integrate the component models.

Organic solar cells based on polymer-fullerene heterojunctions are a promising technology to provide renewable energy that is cost competitive with fossil fuel sources. Critical to the commercial success of this technology is the ability to flex the solar cell during both fabrication and operation. If successful, this research will help guide the development of highly flexible and durable organic solar cells with improved performance over current state of the art devices. Determining the fundamental relationships between the mechanical and electrical properties of the polymer-fullerene film will also provide new insights into the role of film morphology in the energy conversion process and suggest processing strategies that maximize device performance. In addition to the research findings, graduate students involved in the grant will be trained in a highly interdisciplinary research environment. The principle investigators will also contribute to an engineering summer camp for high school students that focuses on solar power technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this research include advancing the knowledge of the microstructural features that influence the mechanical response of electrically conducting organic materials with a focus on polymers and fullerenes used in organic solar cells. Experiments were performed on a number of materials under varied processing conditions that captured the role of microstructure on film stiffness and ductility and the relationship of morphology and device performance. In addition, computational models were developed that were able to capture the complexity of the system including films with multiple materials with multiple material phases. The modeling was able to show how the crystallinity and molecular orientation of the polymer can have a large impact on ductility and strength of the films. As part of this research, large strains were applied to ductile films to modify the film morphology in a controlled manner. This was used as a tool to relate the film morphology to electronic device characteristics in organic solar cells and transistors. Results include the role of polymer orientation on charge transport, and the impact of molecular orientation on energy conversion in organic solar cells. Applying large strain to the photovoltaic active layer was also used in the development of a new photovoltaic device that is sensitive to the polarization state of light. The ability to sense polarized light has many potential applications ranging from biomedical imaging to pollution characterization in the atmosphere.  

Intellectual merit for this research includes providing new knowledge on how film morphology impacts both mechanical and electrical characteristics, providing new insights for the development of mechanically robust flexible organic electronics. New computational models were produced that provide insight into the microstructural origin of the mechanical behavior of these films. This research also showed that the general approach of applying large strains to these films is an effective method to modify film morphology allowing for detailed structure-electrical property correlations. Finally, the polarized photovoltaic device is novel device structure enabled by processing ductile films and applying large strains during the fabrication process. This processing approach was guided by the research findings correlating morphology to film ductility.

Broader impacts of this research include findings that will assist the commercial development of physically robust flexible organic electronic devices. The newly developed structure-property correlations will also assist in commercial development of this technology including devices with novel operating characteristics such as polarization detection capabilities. From an education perspective, there have been 5 graduate students whose research was supported in part by this grant. Two students have been awarded with PhD degrees, and 3 students have been awarded MS degrees, all in Mechanical Engineering. All graduate students involved in the research produced peer reviewed scientific publications. Three undergraduates were also engaged in the research grant through the research experience for undergraduates program. The work of two of the three students resulted in co-authorship of a scientific peer reviewed journal article. Science and engineering outreach was conducted throughout this grant with the PIs leading high school summer camps related to energy related engineering topics. The high school camps directly reached over 200 students and had broad participation from woman and underrepresented minorities. As part of this grant new camp activities were developed that will be offered for many years to come.
